Key Arguments: The proposed legislation grants ACMA substantial, unilateral, and discretionary authority, which could undermine freedom of speech and expression.
The Bill is poorly drafted, with vague definitions of key terms like 'misinformation', 'disinformation', and 'serious harm', making it prone to misuse.
The Bill could infringe on Australia's obligations under international human rights treaties, particularly the ICCPR.
The legislation could impose unacceptable restrictions on individuals posting content online, potentially leading to censorship.
The Bill grants ACMA excessive power without sufficient checks and balances, turning it into a quasi-judicial body with the ability to enforce rules arbitrarily.
Notable Quotes: Such law would render Australia’s commitment to freedom of speech and expression nugatory.
It is a flagrant dismissal of the rights to freedom of speech and expression Australia has covenanted into protecting.
The Bill is, contrary to Lord Hoffman’s well-known judgment, and as outlined above, riddled with generality and ambiguity.

If such law is allowed to pass, it will not only signal the death knell of the internet as a free marketplace of ideas in Australia, but it will signal to Australian citizens, and to citizens of the globe, that the Australian Government seeks total control of the dissemination of information within its borders.
